articles.headline: A Bright Side to Facebook’s Experiments on Its Users
articles.snippet: Studying how social media sites are used can provide valuable insight into human behavior and may also help curb their power and potential for abuse.
articles.abstract: Studying how social media sites are used can provide valuable insight into human behavior and may also help curb their power and potential for abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook’s disclosure last week that it had tinkered with about 700,000 users’ news feeds as part of a psychology experiment conducted in 2012 inadvertently laid bare what too few tech firms acknowledge: that they possess vast powers to closely monitor, test and even shape our behavior, often while we’re in the dark about their capabilities.

articles.headline: Winner in the Amazon War
articles.snippet: A budding writer’s first published novel got a big lift from mentions on “The Colbert Report.”
articles.abstract: A budding writer’s first published novel got a big lift from mentions on “The Colbert Report.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nobody expected much from Edan Lepucki’s debut novel. Her publisher planned a tiny first printing of 12,000 copies. She was assigned to an editor with almost no experience. Was there a marketing budget? How cute of her to ask.

articles.headline: Shrimp’s New Path to the Plate
articles.snippet: Shrimp farmers are trying to meet the growing demand for their product, but in an environmentally responsible way.
articles.abstract: Shrimp farmers are trying to meet the growing demand for their product, but in an environmentally responsible way.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOUGHTON, Mass. — In a warehouse south of Boston, miles away from the city’s bustling harbor, James Tran, a semiconductor designer, is incubating an unlikely product: shrimp.

articles.headline: Gay, Widowed and Fighting for What They’re Due
articles.snippet: Despite government moves to ease the path, a dense legal and bureaucratic thicket often awaits the survivor in a same-sex marriage, advocates say.
articles.abstract: Despite government moves to ease the path, a dense legal and bureaucratic thicket often awaits the survivor in a same-sex marriage, advocates say.
articles.lead_paragraph: While gay rights advocates were encouraged by the federal government’s recent announcement that it would extend more benefits to gay married couples, Gerald Passaro, a 49-year-old former hairstylist, was reflecting on a private victory.

articles.headline: American Apparel Deal Gives Power to Hedge Fund, Not Dov Charney
articles.snippet: Mr. Charney has ceded authority to the investment firm, Standard General, with which he teamed up to retake control of the company he founded.
articles.abstract: Mr. Charney has ceded authority to the investment firm, Standard General, with which he teamed up to retake control of the company he founded.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little-known hedge fund backing Dov Charney, the ousted executive of American Apparel, has emerged as a critical power broker in the battle for control of the struggling retailer.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Dimon’s Cancer and the Fine Line in Revealing Illness of a C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Jamie Dimon chose to go public with his illness, but not all chiefs do.
articles.abstract: Jamie Dimon chose to go public with his illness, but not all chiefs do.
articles.lead_paragraph: The diagnosis came out of nowhere: It was leukemia.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Cheney’s Back, Blitzing Rivals and Drawing Scorn
articles.snippet: Former Vice President Dick Cheney seems reinvigorated as he takes on President Obama, the Clintons, radical Islam, Rand Paul, his own party and history. But to many, he is a punch line.
articles.abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney seems reinvigorated as he takes on President Obama, the Clintons, radical Islam, Rand Paul, his own party and history. But to many, he is a punch line.
articles.lead_paragraph: As his heart failed a couple of summers after leaving office, former Vice President Dick Cheney slipped into a coma and, by his later account, spent weeks dreaming that he was in a countryside villa north of Rome, padding down a stone path every morning to pick up a newspaper or coffee.

articles.headline: Immigration Case Ensnares a Get-Tough Sheriff in South Carolina
articles.snippet: James R. Metts, the state’s longest-serving sheriff, is accused of accepting money from a restaurant mogul to free workers arrested and sent to the county jail he controlled.
articles.abstract: James R. Metts, the state’s longest-serving sheriff, is accused of accepting money from a restaurant mogul to free workers arrested and sent to the county jail he controlled.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, S.C. — The weekday lunch rush arrives as a small ritual of suburban pleasure at the San Jose Mexican Restaurant, just across from the tanning salon and the strip-mall multiplex. A mostly white clientele pulls into a parking lot, past a sign with a cartoon peasant tugging on an obstinate donkey. Inside, a mostly Latino work force serves Americanized versions of Mexican classics as a sound system plays syrupy Spanish ballads.

articles.headline: If Only Thomas Jefferson Could Settle the Issue
articles.snippet: The official transcript of the Declaration of Independence may contain an errant period that contributes to what one scholar calls a “routine but serious misunderstanding” of the document.
articles.abstract: The official transcript of the Declaration of Independence may contain an errant period that contributes to what one scholar calls a “routine but serious misunderstanding” of the document.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every Fourth of July, some Americans sit down to read the Declaration of Independence, reacquainting themselves with the nation’s founding charter exactly as it was signed by the Second Continental Congress in 1776.

articles.headline: Hiring Is Strong and Jobless Rate Declines to 6.1%
articles.snippet: Hiring topped the 200,000 mark for the fifth month in a row as industries as varied as health care, manufacturing, financial services and retailing all added workers.
articles.abstract: Hiring topped the 200,000 mark for the fifth month in a row as industries as varied as health care, manufacturing, financial services and retailing all added workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: American companies are finally getting comfortable enough with the economy’s prospects to add new workers at a very healthy pace, after years of saying they lacked the confidence to hire people aggressively during a fitful recovery.
